message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Capsular polysaccharide vaccines are used to help protect against bacterial infections caused by organisms like Neisseria meningitidis. Smallpox, Corynebacterium diphtheriae, and Clostridium tetani are not known to be prevented by capsular polysaccharide vaccines.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Capsular polysaccharide vaccines are used to protect against bacterial infections caused by organisms with polysaccharide capsules, such as Neisseria meningitidis. Therefore, the correct answer is (B). The other options for vaccines are for smallpox, diphtheria, and tetanus, which have different mechanisms of action and targets in the body.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The only option that is commonly protected by a vaccine containing capsular polysaccharide is Neisseria meningitidis, which can cause meningitis and sepsis. The other options are protected by different types of vaccines or treatments.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Capsular polysaccharides are unique to certain organisms, and in this case, the vaccine is likely to protect against Neisseria meningitidis, which is known to cause meningitis and septicemia. All other options are unrelated to the vaccine.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only Neisseria meningitidis has a capsule consisting of polysaccharides, and a vaccine containing capsular polysaccharides is given to produce antibodies against this organism.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Capsular polysaccharide vaccines are commonly used to protect against bacterial infections caused by organisms like Neisseria meningitidis. Smallpox, Corynebacterium diphtheriae, and Clostridium tetani are caused by different organisms and require different types of vaccines.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Capsular polysaccharide vaccine is used to protect against Neisseria meningitidis, which is a common cause of meningitis and can be deadly if not treated promptly. Smallpox is prevented by a different vaccine, while Corynebacterium diphtheriae and Clostridium tetani are prevented by different types of vaccines as well.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The vaccine containing capsular polysaccharide is most likely the meningococcal vaccine, which protects against Neisseria meningitidis, a bacterium that can cause meningitis and sepsis. The other options refer to different diseases that are not prevented by the meningococcal vaccine.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Capsular polysaccharide vaccines are used to protect against bacterial infections, and among the options, Neisseria meningitidis is the only bacteria that has a capsular polysaccharide vaccine. Smallpox, Corynebacterium diphtheriae, and Clostridium tetani are all caused by viruses and bacteria that are not targeted by capsular polysaccharide vaccines.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Capsular polysaccharide vaccines are typically used to protect against bacterial infections such as Neisseria meningitidis. The other options are not typically prevented using this type of vaccine.
